pain_points_original.title: Ensuring Data Security & Privacy Compliance
pain_points_original.description: The government must guarantee any AI solution complies with strict ICT, security, and privacy policies (IPPs) to safeguard sensitive government data. Failure represents a critical risk to public trust and operational integrity, making robust security a non-negotiable requirement for any tool.

pain_points_original.title: Complex Integration with Existing Systems
pain_points_original.description: DPC faces significant risk integrating new AI tools with its existing government IT systems and third-party LLMs. They need to assess the maturity, scalability, and adaptability of solutions to avoid failed deployments, wasted funds, and disruption to core government operations.

pain_points_original.title: Lack of Market Clarity for Strategic Planning
pain_points_original.description: The government lacks a clear understanding of the current AI market landscape, including available tools, their maturity, and deployment best practices. This knowledge gap hinders their ability to plan future procurements, allocate budgets, and develop a coherent government-wide AI strategy.

pain_points_original.title: Budget Uncertainty & Unclear Cost Models
pain_points_original.description: The DPC cannot proceed with procurement planning without a clear view of AI solution costs and pricing structures. They need indicative pricing to estimate total costs, allocate budgets effectively, and build the financial case for future AI adoption across government agencies.

merge_decisions.kept: Lack of Market Clarity for Strategic Planning
